author: hal stucker
text: interfacestanford profs clifford nass and byron reeves have spent 15 years building personalized agents. they wrote the media equation: how people treat computers, television, and new media like real people and places (cambridge university press) in 1996, and joined agent maker netsage (www.netsage.com) last year. "netsage is ahead of the curve," says chris shipley, executive producer of demo conferences. "it helps people interact with pcs in very human ways." you'll see nass and reeves' handiwork in microsoft office 2000. wired asked what makes their agents so intelligent.wired: tell us about your research.nass: we've taken classic psychology experiments about how people treat others, and applied them to people and computers or web sites.do we interact with computers as if they were human?reeves: the machine gives us cues that we unconsciously recognize as part of social interaction. real-time dialogue, for example - i type something in and something comes back that's contingent on what i typed in.how does this interaction come into play?nass: most everyone fits into one of four personality types - dominant, submissive, friendly, and unfriendly. individuals tend to react favorably to an interface that mirrors their personality type. people with dominant personalities, for example, tend to prefer an interface that makes strong assertions and direct commands.agents have been around for a while, but they haven't always worked - microsoft's bob springs readily to mind.nass: it's been four years since bob, and we've learned a lot about how people respond to characters on a screen.how complex are netsage agents?nass: personality is one aspect. gender, politeness, cooperation, and even humor are other factors. we decide what the agent is going to do, then develop a backstory - each character's likes and life history. this guides the scripting, voice type, animation, and interaction style.what can agents do for me?nass: agents can help you search the web or buy online.what else is netsage working on?nass: computer-generated speech.so agents could soon be selling us stuff on the phone?nass: hey, we never said there wouldn't be a downside to this technology.must readsputterniktired/wiredgood dealas the well turnsall's well that ends wellsmarter bombbattlefield of tomorrowpass it onfashion policewhy buy retail?paranoia technologytailor-made medspeoplejargon watchpersonality typingcustomize or diesailing the red skiesgrubstake grillt1, good buddyraw data
